column1: Just war theory's principle of military necessity belongs to

column3: human procreation
column4: human sociability

column3: authoritarian regimes.

column1: Nagel clarifies that absolutism is the view that we should
column3: avoid murder at all costs
column4: only sometimes prevent murder

column1: Ashford's article is meant to address a particular paralysis in the face of
column2: the sheer scope of global poverty.
column3: having to choose between addressing immediate harm and addressing structural injustice.
column4: reconciling conflict moral theories.

column1: Which of the following does Corvino take to be a problematic "hidden assumption" of harm arguments against homosexuality?
column2: If a practice is riskier than the alternatives, then that practice is moral, prudent, or otherwise to be pursued.
column3: If a practice is risker than the alternatives, then that practice is immoral, imprudent, or otherwise to be avoided.
column4: If a practice is safer than the alternatives, then that practice is immoral, imprudent, or otherwise to be avoided.

column1: Biocentrism is the view that
column2: the only beings that possess direct moral standing are human beings.
column3: all and only sentient creatures have direct moral standing.
column4: all living beings, because they are living, possess direct moral standing.
column5: the primary bearers of direct moral standing are ecosystems in virtue of their functional integrity.

column1: Cases in which a doctor is involved to some degree in assisting an individual to commit suicide are known as
column3: physician-assisted suicide.
column4: involuntary euthanasia.

column1: Carens argues that, for example, liberal egalitarianism has nothing to say about the question of whether a black doctor has a moral obligation to practice in a black community. This is because the only limit that liberal egalitarianism places on individuals' moral obligations, according to Caren, is that they
column2: must not conflict with the rights and duties that liberal egalitarianism itself prescribes.
column3: must be in accord with utilitarian moral considerations.
column4: must not conflict with reasonable standards of prudence.

column1: Which of the following is not a requirement on the definition of "legal punishment"?
column2: It must be for an offense against legal rules.
column3: It must involve unpleasant consequences.
column4: It must not necessarily be of an actual or supposed offender.
column5: It must be intentionally administered by human beings other than the offender.

column1: Richardson-Self argues that sexist speech
column2: is always hate speech, because it involves violence.
column3: is not always hate speech, because it does not involve violence
column4: is always hate speech, because it does not involves violence.
column5: I s not always hate speech, because it always involves violence.

column1: Which of the following is not an objection that Kass makes against cloning?
column3: It threatens identity and individuality.
column4: It will produce harmful biological mutations as clones produce further clones.
column5: It perverts our values concerning parenthood and the raising of children.

column3: an abolitionist.

column2: are incompatible with the right to retaliation.

column4: should be accepted.

column1: One way to value a patient's autonomy is by aiming to maximize his or her effective options. When we value a patient's autonomy in this way, what, according to Velleman, do we value?
column3: the patient's capacity for self-determination
column4: the ability to provide the patient with options

column4: that wealthy nations press their political and economic advantages to secure unfair trade agreements with poor countries.

column3: conservative.

column1: In response to the objection that freedom of association is much more important in the marital context than the political realm, Wellman says
column2: there is no freedom of association in the marital context.
column3: his argument does not require that marital and political freedom of association be equally important.
column4: freedom of association is equally important in both contexts.

column1: Van den Haag responds to the "miscarriages of justice" objection by claiming that
column2: miscarriages of justice are offset by the moral benefits and usefulness of doing justice.
column3: there have been no miscarriages of justice, in the sense used in the objection.

column1: The basic idea of social contract theories of morality is that correct or justified moral rules or principles are the ones that result from
